choices.text: Pseudoexfoliation is seen in old males who had undergone a cataract surgery
Pigmentary glaucoma is seen in young male myopes
Malignant glaucoma is seen after malignancy of eye
Transillumination defects are specifically seen in lens in pseudoexfoliation glaucoma

questions.text: What is true about secondary glaucomas?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Pigmentary glaucoma is a secondary open-angle glaucoma typically seen in young, myopic males and presents with intermittent halos. It results from pigment granule dispersion from the posterior iris surface, which blocks trabecular outflow. Characteristic findings include a Krukenberg spindle on the cornea and a Sampaolesi line on gonioscopy. The prognosis is usually favorable, with minimal field loss in most cases.

Explanation for other options:

Pseudoexfoliation is seen in old males who had undergone a cataract surgery (option A): Seen in elderly eyes but not specifically usually after cataract surgery.

Malignant glaucoma is seen after malignancy of eye (option C): Occurs post-surgical (e.g., iridectomy, cataract surgery) in small hyperopic eyes, not due to ocular malignancy.

Transillumination defects are specifically seen in lens in pseudoexfoliation glaucoma (option D): Defects occur in the iris in pigmentary glaucoma, not in the lens in pseudoexfoliation.

choices.text: Can also cause decrease episcleral venous outflow

questions.text: What is not true about Netarsudil drug?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Netarsudil is a Rho kinase inhibitor used in the management of glaucoma. Its main mechanism is increasing trabecular meshwork (TM) outflow and reducing episcleral venous pressure, both of which lower intraocular pressure (IOP).

It also reduces aqueous humor production slightly. Common adverse effects include conjunctival hyperemia and subconjunctival hemorrhage due to local vasodilation.

However, it is not considered the best drug for primary open-angle glaucoma (POAG) -prostaglandin analogues remain first-line therapy according to standard management protocols.

Key Takeaways:

  • Netarsudil = Rho kinase inhibitor → increase TM outflow + decrease episcleral venous pressure.
  • Causes conjunctival hyperemia and subconjunctival hemorrhage.
  • Used as adjunct/alternative, not first-line for POAG.
  • Mechanism differs from prostaglandin analogues (increased uveoscleral outflow).

Reference:

Netarsudil monotherapy as the initial treatment for open-angle glaucoma and ocular hypertension in

Indian patients: A real-world evaluation of efficacy and safety - PMC

choices.text: Calcium deposits in the sub-epithelium and deep in the stroma
Band-shaped, horizontal opacity that grows from the peripheral cornea towards the central cornea
Hypercalcemia has to be ruled out
Can be seen in chronic silicon filled eyes

questions.text: Band-shaped Keratopathy are all are true except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Band-shaped keratopathy (BSK) is characterized by the deposition of calcium salts (calcium phosphate and carbonate, usually as hydroxyapatite) in the superficial layers of the cornea, specifically the epithelial basement membrane, Bowman's layer, and anterior stroma, not in the sub-epithelium or deep layers.

Explanation for other options:

Band-shaped, horizontal opacity that grows from the peripheral cornea towards the central cornea (option B): True, it typically begins at the periphery and spreads centrally within the interpalpebral zone.

Hypercalcemia has to be ruled out (option C): True, systemic calcium or vitamin D imbalance may underlie the condition.

Can be seen in chronic silicon filled eyes (option D): True, prolonged contact with silicone oil after vitrectomy predisposes to band keratopathy.

Key Takeaways:

  • Calcium deposition occurs in Bowman's layer and superficial stroma.
  • Often secondary to chronic inflammation, hypercalcemia(sarcoidosis, chronic renal failure), or stills disease.
  • Treated by phototheraputic keratectomy or EDTA chelation to restore clarity.

questions.text: A patient was prescribed these glasses. +1 DS / -2 DC at 180 degree. What is this type of prescription
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given prescription is +1 DS / -2 DC at 180°.

  • The first meridian (without cylinder) = +1 D (hypermetropic).
  • The second meridian (after applying the -2 DC cylinder) = +1 - 2 = -1 D (myopic).
    Hence, one meridian is hypermetropic and the other myopic, making it mixed astigmatism.
    Since the correcting cylinder axis is at 180°, the more curved meridian (vertical) is at 90°, which defines with-the-rule (WTR) astigmatism.

Explanation for other options:

Compound astigmatism - WTR (option A): Both meridians must be of the same type (either both myopic or both hypermetropic), which is not the case here.

Simple astigmatism - WTR (option B): Only one meridian should be emmetropic; here, both have refractive errors of opposite types.

Mixed astigmatism - ATR (option D): Would require the cylinder axis near 90°, not 180°.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mixed astigmatism: One meridian myopic, one hypermetropic.
  • WTR (with-the-rule): Cylinder axis ~180°, vertical meridian is more curved than the horizontal.
  • ATR (against-the-rule): Cylinder axis ~90°, Horizontal more curved than the vertical
  • Prescription check: Sphere + cylinder power determines the refractive type of each meridian.

choices.text: Mutation of bestrophin and egg yolk appearance of macula
Lipofuscin accumulates in retina at macula
In all the stage EOG is abnormal, even if the vision is normal
Bronze beaten appearance of macula seen

questions.text: All are true about Best disease except:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Best disease, also known as Vitelliform macular dystrophy, is an autosomal dominant macular dystrophy caused by mutation in the BEST1 (bestrophin-1) gene on chromosome 11q13.

It presents with a bilateral, well-circumscribed yellow "egg-yolk" lesion at the macula due to lipofuscin accumulation between the RPE and photoreceptors.

The EOG (Electrooculogram) is abnormal in all stages of the disease, even when the ERG (Electroretinogram) and visual acuity remain normal, making it a diagnostic hallmark.

The statement mentioning "bronze beaten" appearance is incorrect because that feature is characteristic of Stargardt disease, not Best disease.

Key Takeaways:

  • Gene involved: BEST1 (Bestrophin-1) mutation.
  • Lesion: Yellow "egg-yolk" macular lesion progressing to "scrambled egg" stage.
  • EOG: Abnormal throughout all stages; ERG normal.
  • Vision: May remain normal until late atrophic stage.
  • Differential: "Bronze-beaten" macula = Stargardt disease.

questions.text:
An 65 year old male patient came with complaints of headache since a day . Also complaints of sudden blurring of vision. he is a known case of diabetes and hypertension. He also had a history of stroke an year back.

On ocular examination vision was less than 6/ 60 in both the eyes. Retina was normal. Pupil was normally reacting in both eyes . What is your provisional diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Cortical blindness results from bilateral occipital lobe lesions involving the visual cortex, typically secondary to any vascular lesions like stroke, head injury, tumor or other causes like migrane.

Patients present with sudden bilateral loss of vision but with normal pupillary light reactions and fundus. Visual imagination and visual imagery in dream are preserved,

The history of hypertension, diabetes, and prior stroke supports a vascular etiology.

Explanation for other options:

Migraine (option B): Visual aura in migraine is transient and vision usually returns to normal.

Retrobulbar neuritis (option C): Causes usually monocular visual loss, with intense pain on eye movement, not seen here.

Papilledema (option D): Fundus would show swollen optic discs with blurred margins, which are absent in this case.

Key Takeaways:

  • Cortical blindness: Bilateral occipital infarct → complete vision loss with normal pupillary reactions.
  • Fundus: Normal because the optic nerves are unaffected.
  • Common causes: Stroke, hypoxic injury, head trauma, Tumor, hypoxic encephalopathy, migrane
  • Distinguishing sign: Pupils reactive; patient may have visual anosognosia

questions.text: A 45 year old female came with feeling of grittiness and FB sensation in her eye since many months. She also notices bilateral protrusion of her eye. Her vision, IOP, retina are normal. What is the most likely cause of her ocular symptoms looking at her orbital images
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given symptoms and the radiological image are consistent with thyroid eye disease. The given image shows bilateral, symmetric enlargement of extraocular muscle bellies with tendon sparing- the classic imaging sign of thyroid eye disease (Graves orbitopathy); symptoms are chronic, with surface irritation and preserved vision/IOP/fundus.

Explanation for other options:

Orbital cellulitis (option A): Typically acute, painful, febrile, often unilateral with inflammatory changes and not chronic.

Optic glioma (option B): Primarily optic-nerve fusiform enlargement with visual decline progressively, usually unilateral proptosis.

Hemangioma (option D): Cavernous hemangioma is a discrete intraconal mass causing unilateral progressive proptosis, not diffuse symmetric EOM enlargement.

Key Takeaways:

  • Thyroid eye disease imaging hallmark: EOM belly enlargement with tendon sparing (often spares LR early).
  • Most common adult cause of bilateral proptosis; symptoms include grittiness/exposure from lid retraction.
  • Always evaluate thyroid status; image orbit when needed (US/CT/MRI).

choices.text: BL severe granulomatous uveitis is expected
Retinal vasculitis and macular edema can be seen
HLA b 27 positivity is likely to be present

questions.text: A 30 year old young male presented in OPD with painful right eye since 2 days. On examination there was a mobile hypopyon with a vision of 6/ 60. He also gives history of painful mouth ulcers and joint pains. What is true about this patient's condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The clinical picture given points to Behçet's syndrome, a multisystem inflammatory disorder characterized by recurrent, non-granulomatous uveitis, aphthous ulceration, genital ulcerations and erythema multi-forme.

The ocular disease manifests as acute, severe iridocyclitis with hypopyon and obliterative retinal vasculitis, often bilateral and recurrent. Retinal vasculitis and macular edema are hallmark posterior segment findings that contribute significantly to visual loss

Explanation for other options:

BL severe granulomatous uveitis is expected (option A): False - Behçet's uveitis is non granulomatous, often acute and recurrent.

HLA-B27 positivity is likely to be present (option C): False, it is HLA-B5/B51) is associated, not HLA-B27

There can be a change in color of iris (option D): False - No iris heterochromia; this is seen in Fuchs heterochromic iridocyclitis, not Behçet's.

Key Takeaways:

  • Etiology: Immune-mediated, associated with HLA B51.
  • Ocular signs: Hypopyon iridocyclitis, retinal vasculitis, macular edema, recurrent severe attacks.
  • Systemic features: Oral/genital ulcers, arthritis, neurologic involvement.
  • Complications: Repeated episodes → optic atrophy and irreversible blindness if untreated.
  • Treatment: Systemic corticosteroids and immunosuppressants (azathioprine, cyclosporine).

choices.text: Outer nuclear layer has nuclei of photoreceptors
Muller cells are largest cells In retina spanning across almost all layers
Inner layers of retina, NSR is developed by neuroectoderm
Horizontal cells are responsible for integrating and regulating the input from multiple photoreceptor cells to increase contrast, adapt to different light conditions through a positive feedback

questions.text: What is not true about retinal anatomy
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Horizontal cells indeed integrate signals from multiple photoreceptors and modulate the output of photoreceptors to enhance contrast and aid light adaptation, but this regulation occurs through negative feedback, not positive feedback. Therefore, the statement is incorrect.

Explanation for other options:

  • A) Correct - The outer nuclear layer contains the nuclei of rods and cones (photoreceptors).
  • B) Correct - Müller cells are the largest glial cells in the retina, extending from the inner limiting membrane to the outer limiting membrane, providing structural and metabolic support.
  • C) Correct -The neural retina (NSR) is derived from neuroectoderm.

Key Takeaways:

  • Horizontal cells: Mediate lateral inhibition via negative feedback, crucial for visual contrast enhancement.
  • Müller cells: Span the entire thickness of retina, act as scaffolding and maintain homeostasis.
  • Embryology: Retina and optic nerve develop from neuroectoderm; RPE from outer layer of optic cup.

choices.text: Decreased function of 6th nerve with limitation of abduction
Increased function of 6th nerve with limitation of Abduction

questions.text: Duane's Retraction Syndrome is characterized by
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Duane's Retraction Syndrome (DRS) is a congenital cranial dysinnervation disorder occurring due to paradoxical innervation of lateral or medial or both rectus muscles.

Three types

  • DRS I- limitation of abduction (MC type)
  • DRS II- limitation of adduction
  • DRS III - Both

Usually is caused by absence or hypoplasia of the abducens nucleus/nerve (6th nerve) and aberrant innervation of the lateral rectus muscle by branches of the oculomotor nerve (3rd nerve).

This leads to limitation of abduction and retraction of the globe with narrowing of the palpebral fissure on attempted adduction due to simultaneous contraction of medial and lateral rectus muscles.

Explanation for other options:

  • A) Weakness of SO: Incorrect - the superior oblique muscle (innervated by the 4th nerve) is not involved.
  • B) Overaction of SO: Incorrect - no involvement of superior oblique in DRS.
  • D) Increased function of 6th nerve: Incorrect - the 6th nerve is hypoplastic or absent, not hyperfunctional.

Key takeaways:

  • Type I - Limited abduction, normal adduction.
  • Type II - Limited adduction, normal abduction.
  • Type III - Limitation of both.

choices.text: Surgery for amblyopia is one of the treatment modalities
Occlusion can be done part-time in adults also

questions.text: What is not true about Amblyopia?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Amblyopia is a developmental disorder of vision due to abnormal visual experience during the critical period (birth to 8 years), leading to reduced best-corrected visual acuity without any structural abnormality.

  • Surgery does not treat amblyopia itself surgery can be done to correct strabismus , which causes amblyopia, but not to reverse amblyopia directly.

Explanation for other options:

  • Occlusion can be done part-time in adults also (Option B) True - Although less effective, part-time occlusion therapy can still yield modest improvements in adults, especially with neuroplasticity-based adjuncts.
  • Atropine penalization can be tried (Option C) True -Atropine penalization of the better eye (pharmacologic blurring) is an accepted treatment, especially in moderate amblyopia.
  • Crowding phenomenon is seen (Option D) True - The crowding phenomenon (difficulty in identifying an object when surrounded by others) is a hallmark feature of amblyopia.

Key Takeaways:

  • Mainstay of treatment: Occlusion therapy and penalization during the visual plasticity period.
  • No direct surgical correction for amblyopia, only for underlying causes.
  • Visual training and dichoptic therapy can be helpful in selected adult patients.
  • Prognosis: Better when treated early (<8 years).

questions.text: Equal and simultaneous innervation of yoke muscles is explained by:
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Hering's Law of Equal Innervation states that yoke muscles (a pair of muscles in both eyes that move them in the same direction) receive equal and simultaneous innervation from the brain to ensure coordinated binocular movement.

Example: When looking to the right, the right lateral rectus and left medial rectus act as yoke muscles and are equally stimulated.

Explanation for other options:

  • Sherrington's Law(option B): Describes reciprocal innervation - when one muscle contracts, its antagonist relaxes (within the same eye).
  • Imbert-Fick's Principle(Option C): Related to tonometry, not ocular movements - it explains that intraocular pressure equals the force applied divided by the flattened corneal area.
  • Von Graefe's Law(Option D): Pertains to ocular deviation - describes the secondary deviation in paralytic strabismus being greater than the primary deviation.

Key Takeaways:

  • Hering's Law: Equal innervation → binocular coordination (between eyes).
  • Sherrington's Law: Reciprocal innervation → coordination within one eye.
  • Both are fundamental to normal ocular motility and binocular single vision.

questions.text: A patient presented with pain and redness and vision FC close to face in OPD the next day after cataract surgery. There are cells in Anterior chamber and cornea is very hazy. Retina can't be seen but USG B scan is normal. What is the diagnosis
questions.solution:
Explanation:

TASS is a sterile, non infectious postoperative inflammatory reaction that typically occurs within 12-48 hours after intraocular surgery due to toxic substances entering the anterior chamber (e.g. contaminated irrigation fluids, viscoelastic residue, detergents on instruments, or intraocular medications).

It presents as diffuse limbus-to-limbus corneal edema, marked anterior chamber reaction (cells, fibrin), and decreased vision, but notably with mild pain and no vitritis.

The B-scan is normal, as the vitreous is uninvolved. Early recognition and aggressive topical corticosteroids lead to rapid improvement.

Explanation for other options:

Endophthalmitis caused by Staph. epidermidis (option A): False this presents after 3-7 days with severe pain, hypopyon, and vitritis on B-scan.

Sympathetic ophthalmia, P. acnes (option C): False -sympathetic ophthalmia is an autoimmune panuveitis appearing weeks to months after trauma or surgery, not next day.

Endophthalmitis caused by P. acnes (option D): False - this is delayed-onset (weeks to months) with low-grade chronic inflammation, not acute.

Key Takeaways:

  • TASS: sterile inflammation limited to anterior segment; no vitritis.
  • Onset: within 12-48 h after surgery.
  • Corneal finding: limbus-to-limbus edema with AC reaction.
  • B-scan: normal.
  • Treatment: intensive topical steroids, supportive therapy; identify and eliminate source.

choices.text: Congenital cataract is the cause of leucocoria, cataract surgery should be done
Telangiectatic vessels can be seen in the retina
USG b scan to be done to rule out retinoblastoma
Do a MRI to find out a tumour

questions.text: A 7 year old boy presented with recent onset leukocoria. There is no family history of similar feature. On retinal examination there are areas of exudation. What is the correct statement about this eye condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario describes Coats disease.

Coats disease is an idiopathic congenital retinal vascular disorder seen in young boys, usually unilateral, caused by idiopathic retinal telangiectasia leading to exudation and exudative retinal detachment.

The typical presentation is painless diminution of vision or leukocoria. Fundus shows telangiectatic and aneurysmal retinal vessels with areas of subretinal exudation. There is no family history.

B-scan shows no calcification which differentiates it from retinoblastoma.

Explanation for other options:

Congenital cataract is the cause of leucocoria , cataract surgery should be done (option A): Congentital cataract causes leukocoria since birth and shows lens opacity, not retinal exudation.

USG B-scan to be done to rule out retinoblastoma (option C): Although helpful to rule out retinoblastoma, it describes a diagnostic clue rather than disease related condition.

MRI (option D): Used for detecting tumours like retinoblastoma, not for Coats disease which is non-tumorous.

choices.text: He may have developed a fracture of floor of orbit
Diplopia is due to IR muscle entrapment
X ray may show tear drop sign
Anesthesia near jaw affected side should be checked

questions.text:
A 10 year old boy presented with complaints of enophthalmos and disturbance in vision since few days. He also reports to have injury in his right eye by a cricket ball.

What is not true regarding his eye condition
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario points toward orbital blowout fracture.

A blow-out fracture occurs due to blunt trauma, most commonly involving the orbital floor, leading to herniation of orbital contents into the maxillary sinus.

The sensory disturbance and anaesthesia, when present, is due to infraorbital nerve(V2) distribution(lower lid, cheek, side of nose, upper lip, upper teeth/gums) not "near the jaw" (V3 territory). Hence checking "jaw anesthesia" is not the appropriate sign and the statement is not true.

Explanation for other options:

He may have developed a fracture of floor of orbit (option A): True- Blunt trauma from a cricket ball commonly causes orbital floor blow-out with enophthalmos.

Diplopia is due to IR muscle entrapment (option B): True, diplopia may result from edema/hemorrhage or from mechanical entrapment of the inferior rectus/inferior oblique, especially in trapdoor fractures in children.

X ray may show tear drop sign (option C): True, herniated orbital tissue through the fractured floor produces a teardrop/teardrop opacity in the maxillary sinus on Water's view.

questions.text: If RE has a vision of 6/36 and refractive error of +5 D and LE has +1 D with a vision of 6/ 6. Then what is this refractive condition called as
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Anisometropic amblyopia occurs when unequal refractive errors between the two eyes cause one eye to have chronically blurred vision during visual development. In this case, the right eye has +5 D hypermetropia (causing poor vision 6/36), while the left eye has only +1 D and normal vision (6/6). The interocular refractive difference (>1D hyperopia) leads to suppression of the more ametropic eye and subsequent amblyopia.

Explanation for other options:

Anisometropia (option B): Unequal refractive error between the eyes without established amblyopia. In this case, reduced vision confirms amblyopia, not mere anisometropia.

Malingering (option C): Intentional feigning of visual loss, not applicable here as there is a definite refractive cause.

Refractive amblyopia (option D): Caused by uncorrected high bilateral refractive errors (isoametropic amblyopia), not interocular difference as seen here.

Key takeaways:

  • Hypermetropic difference >1D or myopic difference >3D can cause anisometropic amblyopia.
  • Early optical correction and occlusion therapy are crucial for preventing permanent visual deficit.

questions.text: Incongruous homonymous hemianopia with Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is seen in lesion of
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Lesion of the optic tract leads to incongruous homonymous hemianopia.

Each optic tract contains crossed fibres from contralateral nasal hemiretina and uncrossed fibres from the ipsilateral temporal hemiretina but these nerve fibres from each of these retinal elements are,not closely aligned hence there is incongruous homonymous hemianopia.

The Wernicke's hemianopic pupil is a characteristic feature seen due to disruption of the pupillary reflex pathway fibers in the optic tract. The pupillary light reflex will be normal when the unaffected hemiretina is stimulated and absent when the involved hemiretina is stimulated (i.e. light is shone from the hemianopic side).

Explanation for other options:

Optic nerve (option A): Causes complete monocular blindness, not hemianopia.

Optic chiasma (option B): Causes bitemporal hemianopia due to involvement of crossing nasal fibers, not homonymous type.

Optic cortex (option D): Produces congruous homonymous hemianopia without pupillary abnormality because pupillary fibers do not project to the cortex.

questions.text: A 4-year-old male shown here is referred for evaluation of congenital ptosis. Which of the following abnormal examination findings would you expect to see?
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Congenital ptosis is a condition present at birth, due to failure of neuronal migration which in turn leads to failure of development or function of muscles. The muscle effected is levator palpebrae superioris muscle

The muscle fibers are replaced partially by fibrofatty tissue, resulting in poor or absent levator function. This leads to drooping of the upper eyelid, which may be unilateral or bilateral.

Children with congenital ptosis often elevate their brows using the frontalis muscle and tilt their heads backward (chin-up posture) to improve their visual axis and prevent amblyopia.
On examination, these patients show poor levator excursion and an absent or poorly formed upper lid crease.

Explanation for other options:

Reduced frontalis function (option B): Frontalis muscle function is normal or increased as a compensatory mechanism to elevate the eyelid.

Trigemino-oculomotor synkinesis (option C): This is seen in Marcus Gunn jaw-winking ptosis, not in simple congenital ptosis.

Abnormally high upper eyelid crease (option D): Seen in aponeurotic (acquired) ptosis due to dehiscence of levator aponeurosis, not in congenital ptosis.

Key takeaways:

  • Congenital ptosis → Poor levator function, absent lid crease, compensatory frontalis overaction, possible chin-up posture.
  • Marcus Gunn jaw-winking → Synkinesis between pterygoid and levator muscles.
  • Acquired aponeurotic ptosis → Good levator function with high lid crease.

questions.text:
A 50-year-old man presented to the emergency room complaining of acute onset blurry vision through his left eye. He also described binocular horizontal diplopia, which was worse when looking to the right. Upon waking up that day, he felt he was experiencing a typical ocular migraine, and headache He also had a stroke in 2013.

On check up vertical movements were normal, on left gaze a jerk nystagmus was seen on left side. Where is the site of lesion
questions.solution:
Explanation:

The given clinical scenario points to Right internuclear ophthalmoplegia (INO) due to a lesion of the right medial longitudinal fasciculus(B).

Explanation for answer:

INO results from a lesion of the ipsilateral MLF causing defective adduction of the eye on the side of the lesion and jerky nystagmus of the contralateral eye on abduction

The finding of left-gaze left-beating jerk nystagmus indicates the left eye is the abducting eye, so the adducting eye that fails is the right eye, localizing the lesion to the Right MLF.

Vertical eye movements are intact in isolated MLF lesions and vascular risk factors (prior stroke) support this localization.

Explanation for other options:

L PPRF (option A): Would cause conjugate gaze palsy to the left (both eyes can't look left), not isolated adduction failure with contralateral abducting nystagmus.

L MLF (option C): Would produce adduction deficit of the left eye with right-eye abducting nystagmus on right gaze, not left-gaze left-eye nystagmus.

R third nerve palsy (option D): Produces ptosis, "down and out" position, and pupillary involvement possibly; pattern described is gaze-evoked abducting nystagmus with preserved vertical movements, not a complete CN III palsy.

Key takeaways :

  • L PPRF: Conjugate gaze palsy to the same side (both eyes can't look left).
  • R MLF: Internuclear ophthalmoplegia, adduction defect of right eye with left-beating nystagmus on left gaze
  • L MLF: INO on the opposite side, left eye adduction failure with right gaze nystagmus.
  • R third nerve palsy: Ptosis, eye "down and out," pupil may be dilated; not gaze-dependent.

questions.text: The progression of ocular hypertension to POAG is determined by all except
questions.solution:
Explanation:

Ocular hypertension refers to an IOP consistently above the normal upper limit (usually >21 mmHg), but with a normal optic disc, intact visual fields, and open angles on gonioscopy.

The Ocular Hypertension Treatment Study (OHTS) established several risk factors for progression to POAG.

They are

  • Intraocular pressure - higher the IOP greater the risk.
  • Age - Older age is associated with greater risk
  • Central corneal thickness (CCT) - The risk is greater in eyes with OHT and CCT <555 µm and lower in eyes with high CCT (>588 µm).
  • Cup/disc (C/D) ratio-The greater the C/D ratio the higher the risk.
  • Pattern standard deviation (PSD)- The higher the PSD value the greater the risk.

Hence, a thicker cornea does not contribute to the progression of ocular hypertension to POAG

Explanation for other options:

Family history (option B):
Positive family history (especially in first-degree relatives) is a strong risk factor for POAG due to genetic predisposition.

Advancing age (option C):
The prevalence and risk of developing POAG increase with age, as age-related changes affect the trabecular meshwork and optic nerve head.

Increased CDR (option D):
An increased cup-disc ratio or asymmetry between the two eyes indicates optic nerve damage and is a sign of progression toward glaucomatous optic neuropathy.

Key takeaways:

  • Intraocular pressure (IOP): Higher IOP → greater risk.
  • Age: Older age → higher risk.
  • Central corneal thickness (CCT): Thin cornea (<555 µm) → increased risk; thick cornea (>588 µm) → lower risk.
  • Cup/disc (C/D) ratio: Larger ratio → greater risk.
  • Pattern standard deviation (PSD): Higher PSD → indicates early field changes and greater risk.
